questions.text: A patient presents with complaints of severe left loin pain and burning micturition. His erect abdominal X-ray is shown below. What is the best management for his condition?
questions.solution:
The given abdominal X-ray shows left staghorn renal calculi. The best treatment option for staghorn renal calculi is percutaneous nephrolithotomy (PCNL).

Staghorn calculi is also known as triple phosphate stone. It occupies the renal pelvis and calyces.

PCNL: Endoscopic instruments are passed into the kidney by percutaneous technique and stones are fragmented and removed. It is mainly used in treating large stones and stones in the proximal ureter.

Indications of PCNL:

  • Obstructions caused by anatomical abnormalities like pulviureteric junction obstruction, calyceal diverticula or ureteric obstruction
  • Staghorn calculi
  • Stones >2.5 cm in size
  • Stone composition - struvite, calcium oxalate monohydrate and cystine stones
  • Multiple stones
  • Obese patients in whom ESWL is contraindicated
  • Stones not responding for ESWL

Other options:

Option A: Extracorporeal shockwave lithotripsy (ESWL) is a non-invasive method that generates shockwaves outside the body, which are focused on stones. It is the commonest method of treating urinary tract stones nowadays. 

Stones up to approximately 1.5 cm in size are suitable for this form of treatment. Cystine stones which are often multiple, and very hard are relatively resistant to ESWL due to their hardness. Contraindications for ESWL include obese patients, pregnant patients, and patients taking oral anticoagulants.

Option C: Percutaneous nephrostomy, or nephropyelostomy, is an interventional procedure that is used in the decompression of the renal collecting system.

It is done in grossly unwell patients due to sepsis secondary to an obstructive urinary tract calculi. They drain pus from the kidneys adequately with less manipulation and a lower risk of septicemia than a ureteric stent.

Option D: Ureteroscopic removal is generally preferred for stones <6mm and specifically those present in the distal ureter. Ureteric calculi are directly visualized through semi-rigid ureteroscopes. Stones are then fragmented and extracted using a dormia basket.

Ureteroscopic stone removal using dormia basket is depicted in the image below.

Related Pearl: Management of renal and ureteric calculi

ESWL: Extracorporeal Shock Wave Lithotripsy

PCNL: Percutaneous nephrolithotomy

URS: Ureteroscopic retrieval of stones

Related Pearl: Microscopic Appearance of Various Stones

Xanthine, indinavir, and triamterene stones are radiolucent.

questions.text: An 8-year-old girl presented with fever, increased urinary frequency, and dysuria. The physician suspects a urinary tract infection. What is the most likely etiology?
questions.solution:
Escherichia coli (E. coli) is the most common cause of urinary tract infection (UTI) at any age. It accounts for about 90% of the cases in young women who present for the first time.

The symptoms and signs may include:

  • Fever
  • Urinary frequency
  • Dysuria
  • Pyuria
  • Hematuria
  • Flank pain in upper UTI

questions.text:
A 24-year-old patient presents with a history of urinary frequency, nocturia, and excessive thirst. Her laboratory evaluation results are given below. Brain MRI shows the absence of a bright spot in the pituitary. Her past medical history includes an episode of meningitis. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Urine osmolarity <300 mOsm/L
Urine output >50 ml/kg/day
Random blood glucose 150 mg/dl
Antidiuretic hormone level (ADH) Decreased
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and the lab results indicating increased urine output with low urine osmolarity and decreased ADH levels suggest the diagnosis of central diabetes insipidus. 

Diabetes insipidus can be of two types - central or peripheral (nephrogenic). Central DI occurs due to deficiency of ADH. 

Central diabetes insipidus (DI) is a disorder of the posterior pituitary. It is characterized by decreased ADH leading to large volumes of urine production. Patients present with excessive thirst, nocturia, and urinary frequency. The urine is dilute with an osmolarity of < 300 mOsm/L. The 24-hour urine volume is >40 ml/kg and the basal plasma ADH is <1 pg/ml.

Central DI occurs due to damage to the neurohypophysis in the posterior pituitary. It can be congenital or acquired. In this patient, meningitis has led to the development of DI. 

Central DI can be treated with desmopressin, an ADH analogue. Nephrogenic DI requires treatment with a thiazide diuretic, amiloride, low sodium diet, and indomethacin. 

In nephrogenic DI, ADH levels may be normal or increased because the kidney has become resistant to its effects. The two can be differentiated by the water deprivation test. (Option A)

Option B - Primary polydipsia would have a bright spot on the brain MRI. Primary polydipsia presents with an excessive thirst that reduces the serum osmolarity. There is a compensatory increase in free water excretion that offsets the increased intake to maintain a normal serum sodium level. 

Option D - Syndrome of inappropriate ADH secretion would have increased ADH secretion, concentrated urine, and hyponatremia. 

Related Pearl: Water Deprivation test in Diabetes Insipidus

Procedure: Start the test at 4 am by checking the baseline urine osmolality. Deprive the patient of water till 12 pm (8 hours), and then re-check urine osmolality. 

  Urine osmolality before water deprivation Urine osmolality after water deprivation Urine osmolality after desmopressin administration
Normal  Normal  Increases No change
Central DI Low No change >50% increase from baseline
Nephrogenic DI Low No change <10% increase from baseline
Primary polydipsia Low Increases No change


Note: Normal urine osmolality- 500-850 mOsm/L

Related Pearl: Causes of Central Diabetes insipidus

  • Neoplasms: 
    • Pituitary adenomas (most common)
    • Meningioma
    • Metastasis from lung and breast cancers
  • Infiltrative: 
    • Sarcoidosis
    • Langerhans cell histiocytosis
  • Genetic: 
    • Wolfram syndrome
    • Hand-Schuller-Christian disease 
  • Infections: 
    • Chronic meningitis
    • Viral encephalitis
    • Toxoplasmosis
  •  Inflammatory:
    • Granulomatosis with polyangiitis
    • Lupus erythematosus
    • Scleroderma
  •  Vascular:
    • Sheehan’s syndrome
    • Aneurysm (internal carotid)
  • Head injury (closed and penetrating) including pituitary surgery
  • Snakebite
  • Lymphocytic hypophysitis

questions.text: An elderly woman presented with a mass per vaginum and incontinence. She complains that she has to push the mass inwards to be able to urinate normally. What is the type of incontinence seen here?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario is suggestive of a cystocele in a case of genital prolapse. Stress incontinence is seen in these cases.

In stress incontinence, involuntary leakage of urine occurs when there is increased intraabdominal pressure, such as during laughing, sneezing, or coughing. There is no normal urge to pass urine.

Option A: Urge incontinence is the involuntary voiding of urine when there is an imminent urge to urinate.

Option C: Overflow incontinence is an old term that refers to the inability to empty the bladder, with involuntary, continuous urinary dribbling. Currently, it refers to another presentation of urge incontinence. 

Option D: Neurogenic bladder occurs due to defects anywhere in the pathway of the micturition reflex, e.g., spinal cord trauma, diabetes etc. It presents with with urgency or urge incontinence.

questions.text: A type 2 diabetic patient who was recently started on treatment complains of frequent urination, fever, and burning micturition. Which of the following drugs is most likely responsible for these symptoms?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of a urinary tract infection (UTI). This adverse effect occurs as a result of dapagliflozin use.

The group of sodium-glucose co-transporter-2 or SGLT-2 inhibitors includes drugs like dapagliflozin and canagliflozin. These drugs prevent glucose reabsorption in the renal tubules and cause loss of sodium and glucose. 

  • UTI - due to glucosuria
  • Dehydration - due to natriuresis and volume loss
  • Euglycemic diabetic ketoacidosis - low blood glucose levels due to glucosuria can reduce insulin release

SGLT-2 inhibitors must be temporarily discontinued for 3-4 days before any scheduled surgery to avoid potential risk for diabetic ketoacidosis.

Management of diabetes mellitus
Intervention Advantages Disadvantages
Lifestyle changes Reduced complications and mortality Insufficient for most patients within 1st year
Metformin Weight neutral

GI side effects

Contraindicated when GFR < 45 ml/min
Insulin

Rapidly effective

Lowers HbA1c more than other drugs (by 1.5-3%)

Weight gain

Hypoglycemia
GLP-1 agonists

Weight loss

Reduces cardiovascular complications

 GI side effects
Pramlintide

Weight loss

Lowers postprandial glucose

GI side effects

Hypoglycemia when used with insulin
Sulfonylureas Rapidly effective

Weight gain

Hypoglycemia
Thiazolidinediones Lowers insulin requirements

Weight gain, edema, CHF, fractures
Meglitinides Rapidly effective

Weight gain

Hypoglycemia
SGLT-2 inhibitors

Weight loss

Better cardiovascular and renal outcomes

UTI, vulval candidiasis

Dehydration

Euglycemic DKA
DPP-4 inhibitors Weight neutral Angioedema, urticaria
Alpha-glucosidase inhibitors Weight neutral

GI flatulence

Rise in LFT

The FDA recently approved dapagliflozin oral tablets to reduce the risk of renal and cardiac failure in adults with chronic kidney disease who are at risk of disease progression.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman came to the hospital with complaints of severe burning micturition and fever. On urine microscopy, there were plenty of pus cells. Urine for culture and drug sensitivity was sent.  Which of the following drugs is a urinary anesthetic which can be prescribed in this patient to relieve her severe burning pain during micturition?
questions.solution:
In this case, multiple pus cell in urine is indicative of urinary tract infection. Phenazopyridine can be prescribed in this patient to relieve her severe burning pain during micturition.

Phenazopyridine is a urinary anesthetic. It is used as a local anesthetic in urinary tract disorders to relieve the pain of lower urinary-tract irritation, as in cystitis, urethritis or prostatitis. It does not have any antibacterial action and affords symptomatic relief of burning sensation, dysuria and urgency due to cystitis.

questions.text: An elderly man complains of difficulty in urination, urinary frequency, and urgency for the past month that has progressively worsened. Per rectal examination reveals an enlarged prostate that is non-tender, firm, and smooth. The rectal mucosa is movable over the surface of the swelling. Serum PSA levels are within normal limits. Which of the following zones of the prostate is likely to be involved in this pathology?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is highly suggestive of benign prostatic hyperplasia. The transitional zone of the prostate marked as 'C' is commonly involved in this pathology.

The prostate has three distinct zones as follows:

ZONE STRUCTURES ENCLOSED CLINICAL SIGNIFICANCE
Transitional zone Urethra  The common site for BPH (benign prostatic hyperplasia)
Central zone Ejaculatory ducts Rarely diseased
Peripheral zone

Central transitional zone

Pre-prostatic urethra

 The common site for prostatic carcinoma

The following image shows different zones of the prostate and the structures they encircle.

Note: Some authors regard fibromuscular stroma as a zone, but as per Gray's anatomy, 41e, there are only three distinct zones in the glandular prostate.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male complained of burning micturition, multiple joints pains, and red eyes. Reiter's syndrome is suspected. Which of the following cutaneous feature is likely to be associated?
questions.solution:
Keratoderma blennorrhagica is seen associated with Reiter’s syndrome in 10% of cases.

Reiter syndrome is a systemic disorder, originally defined as a triad of arthritis, urethritis, and conjunctivitis. Cutaneous involvement includes psoriasiform lesions, named keratoderma blennorrhagic um (in about 10%), painful and erosive lesions on the tips of the fingers and toes, nail dystrophy (20-30%) and erythroderma as a rare complication.

In addition, there may be other distinct mucocutaneous manifestations like circinate balanitis, these are small, shallow, painless ulcerative lesions on the glans penis.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man with Parkinson's disease was prescribed mirabegron to control his symptoms of urinary urgency and incontinence. What is the mechanism of action of this drug?
questions.solution:
Mirabegron is a β3 agonist used for the treatment of overactive bladder (OAB). Stimulation of β3 receptors in detrusor muscle increases the bladder capacity and provides symptomatic relief in overactive bladder.

Antimuscarinic drugs are the mainstay of oral pharmacological treatment for OAB. It acts by inhibiting muscarinic receptor subtypes, M2 and M3 in the bladder. Both subtypes are expressed in multiple tissues, resulting in anticholinergic adverse events such as dry mouth, constipation, and cognitive impairment. These adverse effects are not seen with mirabegron as it acts via adrenergic receptors.

Mirabegron is a moderate inhibitor of CYP2D6. Hence, caution has to be exercised when prescribing it along with CYP2D6 substrates such as metoprolol, desipramine, digoxin. 

Related Pearl: Muscarinic antagonists indicated for detrusor instability/overactive bladder

Mechanism/Feature Drug
Direct smooth muscle relaxant  

Flavoxate

Oxybutynin
Bladder selective  

Tolterodine

Fesoterodine (prodrug)
Only quaternary compound   Trospium
M3 selective  

Darifenacin

Solifenacin

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman presented with intermittent suprapubic pain, increased urinary frequency, and dysuria for 2 months. A cystoscopy revealed the presence of Hunner ulcers. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Hunner ulcers are chronic mucosal ulcers that are characteristic of interstitial cystitis or chronic pelvic pain syndrome.

It is a rare idiopathic condition that occurs most frequently in women. It presents with intermittent severe suprapubic pain, urinary frequency, urgency, hematuria, and dysuria.

The following cystoscopic findings are seen in the bladder mucosa:

  • Fissures
  • Punctate hemorrhages (glomerulations)

The microscopic findings include: 

  • Mucosal ulceration covered by fibrin and necrotic material
  • Increased numbers of mucosal mast cells
  • Submucosal edema

In later stages, transmural fibrosis may occur, leading to a contracted bladder. Biopsy must be done to rule out carcinoma in situ, which may clinically mimic interstitial cystitis. 

The following image shows a Hunner's ulcer in a patient with interstitial cystitis.

Related Pearl: Types of Cystitis

Type of cystitis Etiology Characteristic features
Interstitial cystitis Idiopathic Hunner's ulcer
Polypoid cystitis Catheterization of bladder Mimics malignancy
Malakoplakia Defective phagocytosis Michaelis– Gutmann bodies
Eosinophilic cystitis Systemic allergic disorders Submucosal eosinophils
Emphysematous cystitis Clostridium perfringens Associated with Diabetes
Follicular cystitis Prolonged urinary retention, intravesicular chemotherapy or BCG Lymphoid follicles within bladder mucosa
Hemorrhagic cystitis

Cyclo-phosphamide, BK virus, Adenovirus

 Prophylactic administration of mesna reduces the incidence

questions.text: A man presents to the OPD with recurrent attacks of burning micturition and urethral discharge. Gram-staining of the purulent discharge is given in the image below. Deficiency of which of the following complement factors increases the risk of development of this infection?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario along with the microscopic findings of Gram‐negative intracellular diplococci indicates infection with Neisseria gonorrhoeae. A deficiency of membrane attack complex(C5b6789) leads to an increased risk of recurrent Neisseria infections.

Complement factor C5b binds to the late components C6-C9, resulting in the formation of the membrane attack complex (MAC). Neisseria has thin cell walls, hence it is susceptible to lysis to the Membrane attack complex(MAC). Hence, deficiency of this complex leads to an increased risk of recurrent Neisseria infections.

Gonorrhea is a sexually transmitted disease caused by N. gonorrhea. The major symptoms include urethritis, vaginal discharge, dyspareunia, and dysuria. In the laboratory diagnosis of N. gonorrhea, the discharge on Gram's stain reveals gram‐negative intracellular diplococci within phagocytes. It acidifies glucose but not maltose in serum sugars. Stuart's medium is used for transport while Thayer-Martin agar is used as a selective medium used to isolate N. gonorrhoeae. Cultures can be obtained from chocolate agar or Mueller-Hinton agar. 

Stuart’s medium is the transport media used for Neisseria gonorrhea and Neisseria meningitides. It is a semisolid, non-nutrient medium. Charcoal present in the medium neutralizes certain bacterial inhibitors while a reducing agent prevents oxidation.

Related Pearl: Sexually transmitted infections

Genital herpes- caused by herpes simplex virus (human herpesvirus 1 and 2).

  • It appears as blisters (usually multiple) that lead to ulcer formation on breaking.
  • The ulcers are painful.

 

Granuloma inguinale / Donovanosis- caused by Klebsiella granulomatis (formerly known as Calymmatobacterium granulomatis).

  • It usually causes beefy red genital ulcers that may bleed on touch.
  • The ulcers are usually painless.
  • Lymphadenopathy is usually absent but subcutaneous granulomas cause pseudo buboes. 
  • Microscopy shows Donovan bodies with closed safety pin appearance

The given images show genital ulcer in granuloma inguinale:

 

Chancroid/ Soft chancre- caused by Haemophilus ducreyi.

  • Causes genital ulcers that are non indurated with undermined edges.
  • The ulcer is painful.
  • Multiple/ Kissing ulcers develop due to autoinoculation from the primary ulcer.
  • It usually causes tender unilateral inguinal buboes. 
  • Microscopy- School of fish/Railroad track appearance

 

Syphilitic chancre/ Hard chancre- caused by Treponema pallidum.

  • It presents as a small, button-like, indurated ulcer that is usually round/oval.
  • The ulcer is painless.
  • Causes painless lymphadenopathy.
  • Microscopy- Spirochetes seen on dark ground illumination.

 

Lymphogranuloma venereum- caused by Chlamydia trachomatis.

  • It usually presents with a transient single shallow ulcer that heals rapidly and usually goes unnoticed.
  • The secondary stage presents with tender inguinal buboes.
  • Groove sign is seen when the lymph nodes above and below the inguinal ligament are enlarged leading to the appearance of a groove.

The given images show the ulcer and the groove sign seen in LGV:

 

Gonorrhea- caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae.

  • It leads to purulent inflammation of the genital mucous membranes.
  • It may present as urethritis, cervicitis, epididymo‐orchitis, or pelvic inflammatory disease.
  • The usual presentation is acute urethritis with complaints of burning dysuria and purulent discharge.

The given image shows purulent genital inflammation due to gonorrhea:

Related Pearl: Functions of Complement

  • Inflammation: C3a, C5a, and, to a lesser extent, C4a are called anaphylatoxins.
  • C5a is also a chemotactic agent.
  • Opsonization and phagocytosis: C3b and its cleavage product iC3b (inactive C3b) act as opsonins and promote phagocytosis by neutrophils and macrophages.
  • Cell lysis

This role of complement is important mainly for the killing of microbes with thin cell walls, such as Neisseria species, and deficiency of the terminal components of complement predisposes to Neisseria infections.

Related Pearl: Complement deficiency and associated diseases

 

Complement protein Effects of deficiency
C1, C2, C4 Immune- complex disease (SLE)
C3, Factor I Susceptibility to capsulated bacteria
C5-C9 Susceptibility to Neisseria
Factor D. properdin (factor P) Susceptibility to capsulated bacteria and Neisseria.

DAF (Decay accelerating factor)

CD 59

 Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria
C1-inhibitor Hereditary angioneurotic edema

questions.text: A 50-year-old female complains of progressive lower abdominal pain associated with frequent and painful urination. Under antibiotic coverage, cystoscopic examination shows soft, yellow, and raised mucosal plaques. The biopsy study from one of the lesions is given below. Which of the following organisms is the most common cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical condition is described in the given case scenario is Malakoplakia. Escherichia coli is the most common organism involved in this condition.

Malakoplakia is a distinct form of inflammatory reaction seen in chronic cystitis. It is a chronic inflammatory reaction resulting from acquired defects in phagocyte function, commonly affecting the urinary bladder. It can also be seen in other organ systems like the gastrointestinal tract, female genital tract, and the central nervous system. Malakoplakia is seen in chronic bacterial infection, mostly by Escherichia coli or occasionally Proteus species.   Grossly, malakoplakia takes the form of soft, yellow, slightly raised mucosal plaques, often misdiagnosed clinically as malignancy. Microscopically, they are composed of large, foamy macrophages mixed with occasional multinucleate giant cells and lymphocytes. The macrophages have an abundant granular cytoplasm due to phagosomes stuffed with undigested bacterial products. In addition, intracellular deposition of calcium and iron within enlarged lysosomes forms laminated basophilic concretions, known as Michaelis–Gutmann bodies, pathognomonic of malakoplakia.

 The following image shows the Michaelis–Gutmann bodies marked in black arrows.

Related Pearl: Types of Cystitis

Type of cystitis Etiology Characteristic features
Interstitial cystitis Idiopathic Hunner's ulcer
Polypoid cystitis Catheterization of bladder Mimics malignancy
Malakoplakia Defective phagocytosis Michaelis– Gutmann bodies
Eosinophilic cystitis Systemic allergic disorders Submucosal eosinophils
Emphysematous cystitis Clostridium perfringens Associated with Diabetes
Follicular cystitis Prolonged urinary retention, intravesicular chemotherapy or BCG Lymphoid follicles within bladder mucosa
Hemorrhagic cystitis

Cyclo-phosphamide, BK virus, Adenovirus

 Prophylactic administration of mesna reduces the incidence

questions.text:
A young woman complains of burning sensation during micturition, increased urinary frequency, and urgency. She does not complain of fever, flank pain, or colicky abdominal pain. Which of the following is/are the first-line medications used in this condition?
  1. Nitrofurantoin
  2. Ampicillin
  3. Trimethoprim and sulfamethoxazole
  4. Ciprofloxacin
  5. Cephalosporins
questions.solution:
The given clinical sceanrio is suggestive of uncomplicated urinary tract infection (UTI), and nitrofurantoin and trimethoprim and sulfamethoxazole are the first-line drugs used in this condition.

UTI encompasses many clinical entities, including asymptomatic bacteriuria, cystitis, prostatitis, and pyelonephritis. When the infection is confined to the bladder, also known as acute cystitis (the most common manifestation), it is known as uncomplicated UTI. This is more prevalent among women than men. When the infection extends beyond the bladder, causing systemic symptoms and signs, it is known as complicated UTI.

Frequent sexual intercourse, a history of UTI, diabetes, and incontinence are some of the important risk factors of UTI. It is most commonly caused by E. coli. Other species include Staphylococcus saprophyticus, Klebsiella, Proteus, Enterococcus, and Citrobacter species. 

Patients with cystitis typically present with dysuria, urinary frequency, and urgency. Nocturia, hesitancy, suprapubic discomfort, and gross hematuria can also be seen. Fever with a typical high spiking picket-fence pattern and rigors, flank and/or loin pain, nausea, and vomiting are seen in pyelonephritis. UTI can be complicated by the presence of infection, stones or foreign bodies, or delayed response to treatment.

Treatment in a patient with uncomplicated cystitis is started based on history alone. However, if symptoms are not specific or history is not reliable, a urine dipstick test is performed. Emperical treatment can be started in a woman with one symptom of UTI and a positive nitrite or leukocyte esterase result. In case of a negative result, urine culture and pelvic examination are recommended.

Antibiotic therapy include:

  • Trimethoprim and sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SFX) and nitrofurantoin: These are the first-line drugs for uncomplicated cystitis. However, TMP-SFX show high rates of resistance and adversely affect the normal flora in the body. Pivmecillinam, fosfomycin, and nitrofurantoin can be used instead. 
  • Beta-lactam antibiotics: These are the second-line agents due to high rates of relapse and lower pathogen clearance.
  • Fluoroquinolones (ciprofloxacin): These are used for uncomplicated cystitis only if no other alternatives are available due to high rates of resistance and side effects like increased risk of Achilles tendon rupture and irreversible neuropathy. However, they are the first-line drugs for pyelonephritis.
  • Ampicillin and cephalosporins: These are drugs of choice in pregnancy.

Related Pearl: Risk Factors of UTI

Risk Factors for Urinary Tract Infection

Demographic factors

  • Female Gender
  • Male infants (UTI is Males>females during infancy alone)

Structural factors - Any anatomical hindrance to drainage

  • Vesicoureteral reflux (for pyelonephritis)
  • Neuropathic Bladder
  • Pregnancy
  • Constipation
  • Obstructive uropathy
  • Uncircumcised male

Practices & Procedures:

  • Toilet training
  • Voiding dysfunction
  • Wiping from back to front in Females (not males)
  • Tight clothing (underwear)
  • Urethral instrumentation

Infective Factors

  • Pinworm infestation
  • Infection of Bacteria with P fimbriae

Related Pearl: Asymptomatic bacteriuria

 
Asymptomatic bacteriuria: Urinary tract infection without any symptoms. Criteria for diagnosis are as follows:
 
Type of specimen Number of samples required  Minimum colony-forming units (cfu)/mL required for diagnosis of UTI
Midstream clean-catch urine specimen

For women: 2 consecutive samples

For men: single sample

 1,00,000 of the same bacterial species 
Catheterized urine specimen  Single sample

100 for asymptomatic bacteriuria (CA-ASB)

1000 for catheter-associated urinary tract infection (CA-UTI)
Suprapubic aspirate Single sample Any growth of microorganisms in the culture

questions.text: A patient presents with urinary frequency, nocturia, enuresis. 24 hr urine volume was done and found that it is greater than 3 litres. The urine osmolality was 200 mOsm/L. ADH assay was done and the values revealed 0.8 pg/ml. MRI of brain was done and the T1 weighted image did not reveal any abnormalities. The most likely diagnosis is ?
questions.solution:
The given clinical situation suggests Primary polydipsia.

Approach to the question :

  • Greater than 3 litres = Polyuria
  • Urine osmolality < 300 mOsm/ L = Diabetes insipidus, Primary polydipsia
  • Urine osmolality > 300 mOsm/ L = Solute loss (Mannitol infusion, Hypertonic saline)
  • ADH assay normal value = 1 pg/ml
  • ADH assay > 1 = Nephrogenic DI
  • ADH assay < 1 = Primary polydipsia , Central DI

To differentiate Central DI and Primary polydipsia , MRI brain should be done.

  • In case of Primary polydipsia , Pituitary bright spot will be seen.
  • In Central DI , Pituitary bright spot will be absent.

NOTE: In most healthy adults and children, the posterior pituitary emits a hyperintense signal visible in T1-weighted midsagittal images. This “bright spot” is almost always present in patients with primary polydipsia but is always absent
or abnormally small in patients with pituitary DI.

Therefore, when the question says that there were no abnormalities in the MRI, it just means that there is a pituitary bright spot present, because it is a finding seen even in healthy people and hence not considered an abnormality.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male patient presents with a history of purulent urethral discharge and painful micturition for the past 2 days. Why is the following medium used to elicit the growth of the suspected pathogenic organism in this patient?

choices.text: Growth of other commensals is suppressed

questions.solution:
Thayer-Martin medium is shown in the above image, and it is used to isolate Neisseria gonorrhoeae because the antimicrobials present in it suppress the growth of other commensal organisms.

Gonorrhea in males most commonly manifests as acute urethritis - mucopurulent urethral discharge and burning micturition, as mentioned in the given clinical scenario. 

Contents of Thayer-Martin medium includes

  • Vancomycin: to inhibit most gram-positive bacteria
  • Colistin (Polymyxin E): to inhibit most gram-negative bacteria other than Neisseria
  • Nystatin or anisomycin: to inhibit yeast

Note: Contents of Modified Thayer-Martin medium are same as those of Thayer-Martin medium, except that the former contains an additional antibiotic trimethoprim to inhibit proteus.

Since N. gonorrhoeae, N. meningitidis, and N. lactamica are colistin-resistant they can be grown on these selective media.

Gonorrhea in males: 

  • The disease starts as acute urethritis. This infection may extend along the urethra to involve the prostate, seminal vesicles, and epididymis.
  • Chronic urethritis may result in stricture formation.
  • The infection may spread to the periurethral tissues causing abscess and multiple discharging sinuses (water can perineum).

Gonorrhea in females: 

  • The initial infection involves the cervix uteri and urethra which may extend to Bartholin glands, endometrium, and fallopian tubes.
  • The vaginal mucosa is not usually affected in adults because of the stratified squamous epithelium. It is resistant to infection by the cocci, and also because of the acidic pH of vaginal secretions.
  • Pelvic inflammatory disease and salpingitis may result in sterility.
  • Rarely peritonitis may develop with perihepatic inflammation termed Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome.

Other options:

Option A- Enrichment media are liquid media, which allow for the growth of certain organisms and inhibit the growth of others (natural flora). Substances having a stimulating effect on bacteria, which is to be grown, or an inhibitory effect on those to be suppressed are used in this medium. Examples include

  • Tetrathionate broth where tetrathionate allows typhoid-paratyphoid bacilli to grow and inhibits coliforms.
  • Selenite F broth for dysentery-causing bacteria 

Option C - McLeod medium is an indicator medium that contains potassium tellurite. Tellurite is reduced to metallic tellurium by Corynebacterium diphtheriae to produce black colonies.

Option D - Enriched medium: When a basal medium is added with additional nutrients such as blood, serum, or egg, it is called enriched medium. e.g. Lowenstein-Jensen medium is an inspissated selective egg medium containing fresh egg or egg yolk used for the primary isolation of Mycobacterium species.  

Related Pearl: Organisms and selective Culture Media

Appropriate culture media for various bacteria:

Organism Medium for culture

ludlam’s medium

questions.text: A 24-year old female G1P0L0 at 12 weeks of gestation complains of burning micturition, vaginal pruritus, and increased frequency of urination. On examination, her vitals are stable. There is no suprapubic or costovertebral angle tenderness. On per vaginal examination, there is redness of the cervix. Urine analysis is positive for leukocyte esterase but negative on Gram staining. Cervical swab Gram staining also does not show any organisms. Which of the following is the treatment of choice in this patient?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of Chlamydial cervicitis and is treated with azithromycin in pregnant women.

Chlamydia trachomatis is a gram-negative obligate intracellular bacteria and is a common cause of sexually transmitted infections. 

Smears prepared from urethral and cervical secretions are used for diagnosis. As these organisms lack muramic acid in the cell wall, they do not stain well on gram staining. Diagnosis can be made through PCR (gold standard), fluorescent antibody stain, or Giemsa stain. NAATs are the most sensitive tests for these specimens and therefore are recommended for detecting C. trachomatis infection.

Chlamydia trachomatis infection is most often asymptomatic but may present as urethritis, cervicitis, vulvovaginitis, and pelvic inflammatory disease in women. Chlamydial infection in pregnancy can lead to abortion, intrauterine growth restriction, and pre-term labor. Chlamydial infections can be transmitted to the baby during birth causing conjunctivitis, nasopharyngitis, otitis media, and pneumonia.

Treatment with azithromycin (1 g orally single dose) or doxycycline (100 mg BD for 7 days) is advised both to the patient and her sexual partner. In pregnant women like this patient, doxycycline is contraindicated due to teratogenicity. Other drugs which can be used safely in pregnant women with chlamydia include erythromycin and amoxicillin. 

Ceftriaxone (500 mg IM single dose) is added empirically when there is a suspicion of gonococcal infection. It presents with purulent white discharge. In gonococcal cervicitis, gram staining of cervical swabs shows gram-negative diplococci.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient presents to the OPD with complaints of fever, intermittent abdominal pain, and burning micturition. He gives a history of swimming in a freshwater lake 10 days back. Urine microscopy shows the following. Which of the following is the causative agent?

choices.text: Schistosoma species cannot be determined based on egg

questions.solution:
The given clinical picture and image showing an egg that is non-operculated with the terminal spine at one pole are suggestive of infection with Schistosoma hematobium.

Species differentiation of schistosoma can be done based on the location of the spine as follows:

  • Terminal spine- Schistosoma hematobium
  • Lateral spine- Schistosoma mansoni
  • Rudimentary lateral spine- Schistosoma japonicum

The image below shows egg of Schistosoma mansoni. Adult worms of S. mansoni live in the inferior mesenteric vein.

Adult worms of S. japonicum live in the superior mesenteric vein draining the ileocecal region. They are also seen in the intrahepatic portal venules and hemorrhoidal plexus of veins.

The image below shows an egg of Schistosoma japonicum.

 Adult worms of S. hematobium live in the vesical and pelvic plexus of veins.

 The below image shows the life cycle of S.hematobium:

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with dull pelvic pain and burning micturition for 1 year. On per rectal exam, he has mild pain on palpating the prostate. Which is best suited to obtain a culture sample for his condition?

choices.text: Sample obtained after a prostate massage

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of chronic pelvic pain with burning micturition lasting more than a year makes chronic prostatitis the likely diagnosis. In order to obtain an adequate sample for this, a prostate massage is done to elicit prostatic secretions (or threads)which are sent for culture to clinch the diagnosis.

Chronic bacterial prostatitis occurs when either acute infections were not treated adequately or if the patient has had repeated episodes of acute prostatitis.

Clinically, patients present with prostatodynia and dysuria. They can also have sexual dysfunction.

Diagnosis of chronic bacterial prostatitis is done via the 3-tube test. 

  • First voided(10ml) is taken in a test tube. This comes from the urethra.
  • Then midstream sample is taken from the bladder and in the test tube. 
  • Then a prostatic massage is done which gives rise to prostate secretions or threads in the first voided sample post-massage. 
  • These threads are sent for culture.

Treatment:

Antibiotics like ciprofloxacin for 4-6 weeks. 

If the causative organism is chlamydia use doxycycline, if it is trichomonas, use metronidazole.

questions.text: Komal, a high school student developed a fever after she came back from a trip with her friends. She also complained about pain while urinating. She says she has been having these episodes frequently for the past few years. Her father and her grandfather are a known case of cystic kidney disease. Her urine analysis is indicative of UTI with hematuria. Renal ultrasound was done and its findings are shown below. Which of the following chromosomes are associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The presence of multiple cysts seen on the ultrasound(image) along with a positive family history point towards the diagnosis of autosomal-dominant polycystic kidney disease. Chromosomes 16 and 4 are associated with this condition. 

Autosomal-dominant polycystic kidney disease inheritance:

Chromosome involved Chr16 short arm Chr 4 long arm
Gene PKD 1 PKD 2
Protein encoded Polycystin 1 Polycystin 2
Function Transmembrane glycoprotein Non-selective cation channel
Seen in 85 % 10–15 %

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman presents with urinary frequency, urgency, and burning during urination of two days duration. Presence of which of the following additional findings would make you suspect pyelonephritis in this patient?
questions.solution:
White blood cell casts are specific features of pyelonephritis. Neutrophil-rich casts (pus casts) indicate renal involvement because casts are formed only in tubules. 

The urine contains many leukocytes (pyuria) derived from the inflammatory infiltrate.  It is found in both upper and lower UTIs and cannot differentiate between them. Fever is also a non-specific finding.

Ascending infection is the most common cause of clinical pyelonephritis.

Note: Sterile pyuria is defined as white cells in the urine in the absence of significant bacterial growth. It is seen in renal TB.
